paragraphs.text:
%md
# Closeness centrality migration guide

msg.data: Closeness centrality migration guide

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
MATCH p=(:User)-[:FOLLOWS]->(:User)
RETURN p

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Neo4j graph algorithms library

msg.data: Neo4j graph algorithms library

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Streaming closeness centrality

The syntax we have had in graph algorithms library was algo.closeness.stream('Node label', 'Relationship type', {configuration map})

msg.data:
Streaming closeness centrality

The syntax we have had in graph algorithms library was algo.closeness.stream(‘Node label’, ‘Relationship type’, {configuration map})

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
CALL algo.closeness.stream("User", "FOLLOWS")
YIELD nodeId, centrality
RETURN algo.getNodeById(nodeId).id as id, centrality
ORDER BY centrality DESC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
*Alice*, *Doug*, and *David* are the most closely connected nodes in the graph with a 1.0 score, which means each directly connects to all nodes in their part of the graph. David has only a few connections, within his group of friends that’s significant. In other words, this score represents the closeness of each user to others within their subgraph but not the entire graph.

msg.data: Alice, Doug, and David are the most closely connected nodes in the graph with a 1.0 score, which means each directly connects to all nodes in their part of the graph. David has only a few connections, within his group of friends that’s significant. In other words, this score represents the closeness of each user to others within their subgraph but not the entire graph.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Write-back closeness centrality

msg.data: Write-back closeness centrality

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j
CALL algo.closeness("User", "FOLLOWS")

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
loadMillis	computeMillis	writeMillis	nodes
13	1	3	9

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Wasserman-Faust implementation

Stanley Wasserman and Katherine Faust came up with an improved formula for cal‐
culating closeness for graphs with multiple subgraphs without connections between
those groups.

msg.data:
Wasserman-Faust implementation

Stanley Wasserman and Katherine Faust came up with an improved formula for cal‐
culating closeness for graphs with multiple subgraphs without connections between
those groups.

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
CALL algo.closeness.stream("User", "FOLLOWS", {improved: true})
YIELD nodeId, centrality
RETURN algo.getNodeById(nodeId).id AS user, centrality
ORDER BY centrality DESC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md

As Results shows, the results are now more representative of the closeness of
nodes to the entire graph. The scores for the members of the smaller subgraph
(David, Amy, and James) have been dampened, and they now have the lowest scores
of all users. This makes sense as they are the most isolated nodes. This formula is
more useful for detecting the importance of a node across the entire graph rather
than within its own subgraph.

msg.data:
As Results shows, the results are now more representative of the closeness of
nodes to the entire graph. The scores for the members of the smaller subgraph
(David, Amy, and James) have been dampened, and they now have the lowest scores
of all users. This makes sense as they are the most isolated nodes. This formula is
more useful for detecting the importance of a node across the entire graph rather
than within its own subgraph.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Harmonic centrality

Harmonic Centrality (also known as Valued Centrality) is a variant of Closeness Cen‐
trality, invented to solve the original problem with unconnected graphs. In “Harmony
in a Small World”, M. Marchiori and V. Latora proposed this concept as a practical
representation of an average shortest path.
When calculating the closeness score for each node, rather than summing the distances
of a node to all other nodes, it sums the inverse of those distances. This means
that infinite values become irrelevant.

msg.data:
Harmonic centrality

Harmonic Centrality (also known as Valued Centrality) is a variant of Closeness Cen‐
trality, invented to solve the original problem with unconnected graphs. In “Harmony
in a Small World”, M. Marchiori and V. Latora proposed this concept as a practical
representation of an average shortest path.
When calculating the closeness score for each node, rather than summing the distances
of a node to all other nodes, it sums the inverse of those distances. This means
that infinite values become irrelevant.

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
CALL algo.closeness.harmonic.stream("User", "FOLLOWS")
YIELD nodeId, centrality
RETURN algo.getNodeById(nodeId).id AS user, centrality
ORDER BY centrality DESC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
user	centrality
"Alice"	0.625
"Doug"	0.625
"Bridget"	0.5
"Michael"	0.5
"Charles"	0.4375
"Mark"	0.4375
"David"	0.25
"Amy"	0.1875
"James"	0.1875

paragraphs.text:
%md

The results from this algorithm differ from those of the original Closeness Centrality
algorithm but are similar to those from the Wasserman and Faust improvement.
Either algorithm can be used when working with graphs with more than one connec‐
ted component.

msg.data:
The results from this algorithm differ from those of the original Closeness Centrality
algorithm but are similar to those from the Wasserman and Faust improvement.
Either algorithm can be used when working with graphs with more than one connec‐
ted component.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Neo4j graph data science library

msg.data: Neo4j graph data science library

paragraphs.text:
%md
Preferred way to use GDS library is with loaded named graphs, where we first load the graph into memory and then proceed to run algorithms on it.

msg.data: Preferred way to use GDS library is with loaded named graphs, where we first load the graph into memory and then proceed to run algorithms on it.

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_gdn
CALL gds.graph.create('closeness_example', 'User', 'FOLLOWS')

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
graphName	nodeProjection.User.label	relationshipProjection.FOLLOWS.aggregation	relationshipProjection.FOLLOWS.projection	relationshipProjection.FOLLOWS.type	nodeCount	relationshipCount	createMillis
"closeness_example"	User	DEFAULT	NATURAL	FOLLOWS	9	16	5

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Streaming closeness centrality

msg.data: Streaming closeness centrality

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_gdn
CALL gds.alpha.closeness.stream('closeness_example') YIELD nodeId, centrality
RETURN gds.util.asNode(nodeId).id AS name, centrality ORDER BY centrality DESC LIMIT 10

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Write-back closeness centrality

msg.data: Write-back closeness centrality

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_gdn
CALL gds.alpha.closeness.write('closeness_example', {writeProperty:'closeness'});
